title: 107_hr2787
content:
SECTION 1. REFERENCE. This Act amends sections of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. SEC. 2. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. Congress makes the following findings: Two-thirds of mothers with children under 6 years old are in the workforce. Over 10 percent of children under 6 have a disability, with higher rates in low-income communities. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates early intervention services for infants and toddlers with disabilities in a natural environment. Special education preschool services are also required under this Act. The General Accounting Office reports limited availability of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours, especially in low-income communities. Children with disabilities or special health care needs face barriers in accessing child care programs due to misconceptions. The purpose of this Act is to increase quality child care for children with disabilities by addressing barriers in accessing child care programs due to misconceptions and lack of staff training. SEC. 3. APPLICATION AND PLAN. Amends Section 658E(c) to include families with children with disabilities. SEC. 4. ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF CHILD CARE. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to include activities for children with disabilities, requiring states to use at least 5 percent of funds for this purpose. States must allocate at least 5 percent of funds for activities to increase quality child care for children with disabilities, including training and technical assistance for child care providers. The curr_chunk discusses a comprehensive system of training and technical assistance for child care providers, state licensing agencies, and parents to collaborate on implementing the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The curr_chunk focuses on providing technical assistance and training to family home and center child care providers to include children with disabilities in child care settings. This includes training on assistive technology and leadership skills for child care directors. The curr_chunk focuses on providing leadership training for child care directors to operate inclusive child care programs for children with disabilities. This includes skills in financial development, program development, parent education, and community development. Additionally, assistance is provided to child care resource and referral agencies on compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Grants are provided for recruitment and retention of qualified staff in child care, including scholarships for staff to obtain degrees. Grants are available for child care staff to obtain degrees in child development, increase their salaries, and retain qualified providers in the field. The Secretary can provide grants and low-interest loans to public agencies and nonprofit organizations for projects that increase availability of inclusive child care programs, child care for infants, and child care during evenings and weekends. SEC. 5. REPORTS.

Amendment to Section 658K(a)(1)(B)(iii) (42 U.S.C. 9858i(a)(1)(B)(iii)) by adding "disability status".

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Section 658P (42 U.S.C. 9858n) is amended to include definitions for "child with a disability" and "inclusive child care program." An inclusive child care program serves both children with disabilities and children without disabilities together, with no more than 50 percent of the children enrolled being children with disabilities.
